results.title: Animated
results.brief_description: An off-the-wall, engagingly funny, slightly serious and brilliantly assembled collection of the maddest moments of Australia’s unsung film art. A film which rolls 75 years of history into 80 rip roaring minutes of fun and hi-jinx.

results.title: Animals: ways they move
results.brief_description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.
results.description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.

results.title: Animals: ways they eat
results.creator_credit: William A. Anderson and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows how the body parts of various animals are related to their eating habits. Includes such examples as the cirri or barnacles, the mouth parts and legs of crayfish, the teeth of lions and cows, the tongues of butterflies, the noses of hogs, the beaks of birds, and the paws of squirrels.

results.title: Animals without backbones
results.brief_description: What kinds of structures do these animals have? How do such bodies move about? How are their bodies supported? Nature photography points out the characteristics of the anthropods, spiny-skinned animals, molluscs, sponges, bag-like animals, and earthworms, and shows these animals carrying out some of their life functions.

results.brief_description: Shows how animals adapted to life in the intertidal zone survive the hazards of the surf.

results.title: Animals that build
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: This film focuses on animals as engineers, constructing elaborate dwellings and protection devices. From tiny microscopic creatures like coral, insects like spiders and caterpillars through to birds and mammals like beavers and man, the program provides a useful insight into the natural world. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Animals see in many ways
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Presents a basic introduction to the ways in which different animals see. Shows that some animals have simple eyes and some have compound eyes, highlighting how these two eye-types function and how they aid the particular animal in functioning within its environment, eg the differences between the eye-types of hunted and hunter animals. Also defines lens, retina and iris. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Animals of the zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to a zoo at feeding time, provides an opportunity to study the food and eating habits of various animals: lion, tiger, gorilla, chimpanzee, eland, bison, black and polar bears. Also contains a rare short sequence of a Tasmanian tiger, referred to as a wolf dog. Habitats and characteristics of each are described.

results.title: Animals of the rocky shore [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Scottish Marine Biological Station and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: This film is a simple ecological study of animals whose structure and habits enable them to live on rocky shores both above and below the low-tide mark. The following animals are seen: the common starfish, brittle star, sea urchin, sea stickleback and gobies, the swimming crab, the whelk, the hermit crab (seen climbing into a shell), sea anenomes, polyp clava, and the sea-aquirt ciona. Between tide-marks on the exposed rock surface, mussels, limpets, winkles, and acorn barnacles are seen. The whole series of animals is related to problems of life on the rocky shore.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gaumont-British Instructional, Scottish Marine Biological Station and J.V. Durden

results.title: Animals of the rocky shore
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Hugh Baddeley Productions
results.brief_description: This film presents creatures of the rocky shore. Close-ups of crabs are shown, revealing the complexity of the mouth parts. In deeper water mullet, pollack and bass are shown swimming. An egg-case is removed from a dogfish and the developing embryo is shown.
